title: Excel Functions and Charts Practice: Party Planning Dataset

steps.title: Basic Functions Practice
steps.content:
Practice: Working with SUM and COUNTA Functions

For this set of activities, you will need the party_planning_dataset file.

This can be found in the FUNCTIONS & CHARTS section under the Excel Skills page on Aidan's Central.

Create a New Worksheet

First, create a new sheet named 'Basic Functions' to store your results.

Exercise 1: Add Recipe Count Column

Using the 'Recipe ingredients' sheet, you'll notice columns J, K, and L already contain Maximum, Minimum, and Total calculations. Let's add a new column to count recipe usage:

  1. In cell M1, add the header 'Recipe Count'.
  2. In cell M2, use the COUNTA function to count how many recipes use baking powder (first ingredient).
  3. Use the formula: =COUNTA(C2:I2)
  4. Copy this formula down to calculate recipe counts for all ingredients (rows 2-22).
  5. In your 'Basic Functions' sheet, paste the ingredient names (column A) and their recipe counts (column M).
Exercise 2: Create SUM Calculations

Now let's create the Total column calculations that are missing:

  1. In cell L1, add the header 'Total' if it's not already there.
  2. In cell L2, create a SUM formula to calculate the total amount of baking powder across all recipes.
  3. Use the formula: =SUM(C2:I2)
  4. Copy this formula down to calculate totals for all ingredients (rows 2-22).
  5. In your 'Basic Functions' sheet, create a summary table:
    • Column A: Copy ingredient names from the Recipe ingredients sheet, column A, rows 2-22
    • Column B: Copy recipe count values from the Recipe ingredients sheet, column M, rows 2-22
    • Column C: Copy total amounts from the Recipe ingredients sheet, column L, rows 2-22
    • Add headers in row 1: A1='Ingredient', B1='Recipe Count', C1='Total Amount'

quiz.question: What is the difference between SUM and COUNTA functions?
options: SUM adds numbers together, COUNTA counts non-empty cells
SUM counts cells, COUNTA adds numbers

steps.title: Advanced Functions Practice
steps.content:
Practice: Using MAX and MIN Functions

Create a New Worksheet

Create a new sheet named 'Advanced Functions'.

Exercise 1: Create MAX Functions

Let's add Maximum value calculations to the dataset:

  1. In cell J1, add the header 'Maximum' if it's not already there.
  2. In cell J2, create a MAX formula to find the highest amount of baking powder used in any single recipe.
  3. Use the formula: =MAX(C2:I2)
  4. Copy this formula down to find the maximum amount for each ingredient (rows 2-22).
  5. Now filter to show only ingredients with high maximum values:
    • Select the entire data range (A1:M22)
    • Go to Data tab → Filter (this adds dropdown arrows to your headers)
    • Click the dropdown arrow in the Maximum column (column J)
    • Choose 'Number Filters' → 'Greater Than' → type '100' → OK
  6. Copy the filtered results to your 'Advanced Functions' sheet:
    • Select and copy the visible filtered rows from columns A and J (ingredient names and maximum values)
    • Paste into your 'Advanced Functions' sheet starting at A1
    • Add headers: A1='Ingredient', B1='Maximum Value'
Exercise 2: Create MIN Functions

Now let's add Minimum value calculations:

  1. Return to the 'Recipe ingredients' sheet and clear any filters (Data → Filter to toggle off).
  2. In cell K1, add the header 'Minimum' if it's not already there.
  3. In cell K2, create a MIN formula to find the smallest amount of baking powder.
  4. Use the formula: =MIN(C2:I2)
  5. Copy this formula down to all ingredient rows (rows 2-22).
  6. In your 'Advanced Functions' sheet, add the minimum data:
    • Copy ingredient names from column A, rows 2-22 of the Recipe ingredients sheet
    • Paste into column C of your Advanced Functions sheet
    • Copy minimum values from column K, rows 2-22 of the Recipe ingredients sheet
    • Paste into column D of your Advanced Functions sheet
    • Add headers: C1='Ingredient', D1='Minimum Value'

quiz.question: If you want to find the largest value across multiple non-adjacent ranges, which formula structure would work?

steps.title: Chart Creation Practice
steps.content:
Practice: Visualising Recipe Data

Create a New Worksheet

Create a new sheet named 'Charts Practice'.

Exercise 1: Ingredient Usage Chart

Create a column chart showing how caster sugar is used across recipes:

  1. On the 'Recipe ingredients' sheet, select the range A1:I1 (headers) and A7:I7 (caster sugar row) while holding Ctrl.
  2. Go to the Insert tab at the top of the ribbon.
  3. Click 'Recommended Charts'.
  4. Select 'Column or Bar Chart' and choose '2-D Clustered Column'.
  5. Customise your chart:
    • Title: 'Caster Sugar Usage Across Recipes'
    • Add data labels by clicking the + button next to the chart
  6. Copy this chart to your 'Charts Practice' sheet.
Exercise 2: Recipe Summary Chart

Create a chart showing recipe complexity using your own calculations:

  1. In your 'Charts Practice' sheet, create a summary table starting at cell A1:
    • A1: Type 'Recipe Name'
    • B1: Type 'Ingredient Count'
    • A2-A8: Copy recipe names from the Recipe ingredients sheet, row 1, columns C through I
    • B2-B8: For each recipe, count ingredients using COUNTA:
      • B2: =COUNTA('Recipe ingredients'!C2:C22)
      • B3: =COUNTA('Recipe ingredients'!D2:D22)
      • Continue for all recipes through column I
  2. Select your complete summary table (A1:B8).
  3. Go to the Insert tab at the top of the ribbon.
  4. Click 'Recommended Charts'.
  5. Find and select the Pie Chart option.
  6. Customise your chart:
    • Title: 'Recipe Complexity by Ingredient Count'
    • Add data labels showing both values and percentages (click + button next to chart)
    • Different colours for each recipe (should be automatic)
Exercise 3: Maximum Values Chart

Create a chart showing which ingredients have the highest maximum values:

  1. Return to the 'Recipe ingredients' sheet.
  2. Filter for high-value ingredients:
    • Select the entire data range (A1:M22)
    • Go to Data tab → Filter (adds dropdown arrows if not already there)
    • Click the dropdown arrow in the Maximum column (column J)
    • Choose 'Number Filters' → 'Greater Than' → type '200' → OK
  3. Copy the filtered data to create your chart:
    • Select and copy the visible ingredient names (column A) from the filtered results
    • Paste into your 'Charts Practice' sheet starting at cell A12
    • Select and copy the corresponding maximum values (column J) from the filtered results
    • Paste into your 'Charts Practice' sheet starting at cell B12
    • Add headers at A11='Ingredient' and B11='Maximum Value'
  4. Create the chart:
    • Select your data range (A11 through B and however many rows you have)
    • Go to Insert → Recommended Charts → choose Bar Chart (horizontal bars work better for ingredient names)
    • Title: 'Highest Ingredient Amounts Across All Recipes'

quiz.question: Which chart type is most appropriate for showing parts of a whole?

steps.title: Function Combinations Practice
steps.content:
Practice: Advanced Function Applications

Create a New Worksheet

Create a new sheet named 'Function Combinations'.

Exercise 1: Create Summary Analysis

Create a comprehensive analysis at the bottom of the ingredients sheet:

  1. In your 'Function Combinations' sheet, create a summary analysis:
    • A1: 'Number of ingredients in each recipe:'
    • B1:H1: Recipe names (copied from C1:I1 of the ingredients sheet)
    • B2:H2: Use COUNTA to count ingredients per recipe: =COUNTA(C2:C22) for each recipe column
  2. Add row 3:
    • A3: 'Total number of ingredients listed:'
    • B3: Use COUNTA(A2:A22) to count all ingredient names
  3. Add row 4:
    • A4: 'Average ingredients per recipe:'
    • B4: Calculate using =AVERAGE(B2:H2)
Exercise 2: Advanced Recipe Analysis

Create a comprehensive analysis combining multiple functions:

  1. Create a detailed comparison table starting in row 6:
    • Row 6: Headers - Recipe Name, Ingredient Count, Total Amount, Highest Single Amount, Average per Ingredient
    • Row 7 onwards: For each recipe, calculate:
      • Ingredient count: Use your COUNTA formulas from row 2
      • Total amount: Use SUM to add up the entire recipe column from the ingredients sheet
      • Highest amount: Use MAX on the recipe column
      • Average per ingredient: Calculate Total ÷ Count
  2. Use conditional formatting to highlight:
    • Recipe with most ingredients (green)
    • Recipe with highest total amount (red)
    • Most efficient recipe (lowest average per ingredient) (blue)
  3. Create a combination chart showing both ingredient count and total amount for easy comparison.
Submit Your Work

Once you've completed all exercises, your Excel file should contain these sheets:

  • Basic Functions
  • Advanced Functions
  • Charts Practice
  • Function Combinations

Save your file and submit it on Aidan's Central under the FUNCTIONS & CHARTS section.

quiz.question: When combining multiple functions in Excel, what's the most important consideration?
options: Using the most advanced functions possible
Ensuring the functions work together logically to solve the problem
Making the formula as short as possible
Using only SUM and COUNT functions
